content: This was my first ever hackathon experience and one of the most memorable ones.

My team and I had 20ish hours to develop an application that would show past and future rocket launches in different locations around the world. We decided to categorize the launches by place and time and show them on an interactive map with a 'cool' design.

For this challenge we decided to use Python's Dash library for web data visualization. We didn't know the tool at the time so it was quite a challenge to learn it, as the library was pretty fresh lacking documentation and active community.

This project was inspired by one of Google's <a href="https://www.google.com/doodles/fahrelnissa-zeids-118th-birthday">doodles<a>. Logeomio is a tool for representing words (logos) as a collection of geometrical figures.
The math behind the scenes is written using p5.js - a simplified JS library for drawing simple visuals in web.

This project was born when I was solving an interesting challenge on Kaggle. The challenge was to build a shortest path through a set of points (or Travelling Salesman Problem), but with a slight twist: if the index of a point in the sequence is a prime number, then the distance to it from the previous one increases by 10%

The TSP problem got me interested and I decided to code a solution from scratch using different algorithms (despite tons of existing solutions) to better understand the problem and to practice developing a C++ library.
